name: torreya-taxifolia
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Male cones appear in the axils of the needles of the prior year. Female cones appear in the axils of the needles of the current year and take 18 months to ripen. A fleshy drupe-like cone is up to 1.3 inches long and surrounds a single seed. Fruits are striped with purple and the seed matures to reddish-brown. Squirrels help disperse the seeds.
leaf-description: Bright green, stiff, glossy linear needles 1 1/2-2" long and 1/8" wide, have an unpleasant fragrance when crushed.  Two bluish-white stomatal bands run on the bottom side of the leaves.
bark-description: Mature bark is thick and irregularly divided by shallow fissures. The dark-brown outer bark often is tinged with orange while the inner bark is yellow.
stem-description: Stiff green twigs. 2-year old branches gray. Stems emit a foul odor when crushed.
uses: Had been used for fence posts
